nodes.title: II.2. Superficial structures: Primarily funerary superstructure
Site elements
nodes.body: Funerary structures FS1 to FS4 form a single line of structures on the edge of the hillside (4400 m). They are all situated at the same elevation. The uphill flanks of these structures are flush with the slope while their downhill flanks are elevated around 1 m above the slope.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS2
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS2 (5.5 m x 7 m) also has a verge lined in masonry of no particular design (34.483΄ / 90.149΄). The stones appear to have been laid in a haphazard fashion.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS3
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS3 (3.6 m x 4) has a verge partially lined with stones (34,483΄ / 10.154΄).

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS4
nodes.body: In recent years, funerary structure FS4 has been excavated to a depth of 1 m by local residents in their quest for valuable artifacts and building materials (stones are used to build corrals and other structures.) (34.477΄ / 10.161΄). This excavation penetrated to the bottom of the structure. The stones were hauled away by truck as evidenced by deep tire tracks that still scar the hillside. It is reported that human bones and ceramic shards were found inside FS4. No traces of these objects remain visible at the site. Many stones (up to 80 cm long) were left in a pile beside where FS4 once stood. It appears from local testimonies, that the subsurface architecture of FS4 consisted of a stone-lined burial chamber. This rock laden structure contrasts with the adjoining slopes, which are free of stones.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS5
nodes.body:
Funerary structure FS5 is situated approximately 5 m below the FS1 to FS4 line of tombs (30.476΄ / 10.139΄). Only some of the stones forming its verge are still in situ. FS5 is level with the uphill slope and elevated about 1 m above the downhill slope. It is quite possible that there is another terraced funerary structure next o FS5 but it has been totally engulfed by dramagra ma brush (34.475΄ / 10.150΄).

There is another possible funerary mound on the same ridgeline, but it is too degraded to positively identify hrough visual means (34.334΄ / 10.246΄ / 4370 m).
